Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Story: I sat at my desk, staring at the blinking cursor on my screen. As a colleague, I knew I was expected to finish the project summary by Friday, but with the generous buffer time, no one would be held up if I took a little longer. Still, I could already hear my teammate’s voice in my head, “Let’s keep things moving, okay?” At the same time, the lab schedule beckoned. As a scientist, I was supposed to run the next experiment to test our new hypothesis. The equipment was available today, but there were plenty of open slots next week too. Skipping this session wouldn’t derail our research, but I felt the familiar tug of responsibility—what if I missed a breakthrough by waiting? My mind spun with the competing demands: be a reliable teammate, be a diligent scientist. I felt the pressure building, the weight of expectations from both sides pressing in, and I wondered which role I should honor first.
